column1: The first settlers began moving into the Humble area in the early 19th century. Joseph Dunman is  believed to be the first settler in 1828. A ferry was built nearby
column2: across the San Jacinto River. The area of Humble became a center for commercial activity due to the region's large oil industry.The city got its name from one of the original founders/settlers
column3: Pleasant Smith Humble
column4: who opened the first post office in his home and later served as justice of the peace. In 1883
column5: a city directory reported that he operated a fruit stand. In 1885
column11: Texas Census reported his occupation as attorney at law.

column1: Downtown Humble is located on a salt dome. Most of the petroleum production is shallow and encircles the city by about a 2.5-mile (4.0 km) radius.
The climate in this area is characterized by hot
column2: humid summers and generally mild to cool winters.  According to the Köppen Climate Classification system
column3: Humble has a humid subtropical climate

column1: Harris County operates a tax office at 7900 Will Clayton Parkway in Humble.The U.S. Postal Service operates the Humble Post Office. Some locations in the City of Houston have Humble mailing addresses.
Humble is served by the Humble Independent School District.
The city of Humble has three public elementary schools:

column2: Senior Elementary School

column1: Lakeland Elementary SchoolHumble is served by Ross Sterling Middle School (formerly by Humble Middle School)
column2: and Humble High School

column1: All students attending the Humble Independent School District have the option to apply to Quest High School
column2: a magnet high school that as of the 2016–2017 school year is contained within but separated from Humble High School.

column1: Aldine Independent School District is constructing Jones Middle School (initially named Townsen Boulevard Middle School) in the Humble city limits.A Catholic K-8
column2: St. Mary Magdalene School
column3: is in Humble. The closest Catholic high school is Frassati Catholic High School in north Harris County; the planners of the school intended for it to serve Humble. Holy Trinity Episcopal School

column1: Lone Star College System (formerly the North Harris Montgomery Community College District) serves the area. In 1972
column2: residents of Humble ISD and two other K–12 school districts voted to create the North Harris County College District. The community college district began operations in the Harris County/Montgomery County's northern hemisphere in the fall of 1973. The Humble area is currently served by Lone Star College
column3: Kingwood which operates the Humble Center for outreach.

column1: The Harris County Public Library Octavia Fields Branch Library is located at 1503 South Houston Avenue in Humble. Humble's first public library opened in 1921 with the books stored in the high school. In 1923 the library was split between the Humble High School and the Woodward School at Moonshine Hill. In 1926 the library moved to a church. In 1928 the library moved into the then-new Humble courthouse. In the early 1930s the library moved to city hall. In 1932 the city hall courtroom became a reading room. In the early 1960s a man named Tom Shelton donated a house and lot at the intersection of First Street and Avenue D. The house was remodeled and opened as the Shelton Memorial Library. On October 9
column2: 1969 the library moved to 111 West Higgins Street. It received the name Octavia Fields Memorial Library from Octavia Fields
column3: the grandmother of Jack Fields
column4: a former Congress member. The current 15

column10: a German settler. His descendants deeded the homestead to Harris County. The plans stated that the Boettcher staff would assist the Mercer Park staff in finding any botanical reference books that they or the public need.

column1: Humble news is covered by three community newspapers: Community Impact Newspaper Lake Houston/Humble/Kingwood edition (website)
column2: The Tribune Newspaper (website) and The Observer Newspaper. Community Impact Newspaper is owned by John and Jennifer Garrett and covers several Houston Metro suburban areas as well as Austin and DFW Metro markets. The Tribune is locally owned and operated by Cynthia Calvert and Larry Shiflet. The Observer is owned by the Hearst Publications. It is also the business location of Christian Radio Station KSBJ ksbj.org
column3: call sign 89.3 FM radio.

column1: Harris County Hospital District operates the E. A. "Squatty" Lyons Health Center in Humble. The clinic opened in 1991
column2: replacing a clinic in Bordersville.Humble Surgical Hospital is a multi-specialty
column3: physician-owned surgical hospital. Humble Surgical Hospital opened in 2010.

column1: The United States Postal Service Humble Post Office is located at 1202 1st Street East. The Foxbrook Finance Unit is located near Humble in an unincorporated area; On Monday May 10
column3: the Foxbrook post office was dedicated as the "Texas Military Veterans Post Office" in a ceremony hosted by U.S. Congressperson Ted Poe.
